  • dragon.native.process_group
  • View page source

dragon.native.process_groupÔÉÅ

The Dragon native class for managing the life-cycle of a group of Dragon processes.

The intent is for the class to be agnostic about what the processes are doing, it only maintains their lifecycle.

This file implements a client API class and a Manager process handling all groups on the node. The manager holds a list of GroupContext classes and gets signals from the client classes using a queue. The group of processes undergoes state transitions depending on the signals the client send to the manager.

Due to transparency constraints the manager cannot send information back to the client. Instead we are using shared state

The underlying state machine looks like this:

Classes

BaseState

This class declares methods that all concrete State classes should implement and also provides a backreference to the Context object, associated with the State.

Error

This is the fallback state if an issue with the group occurs.

GroupContext

The Context defines the group interface for the manager and the client.

Idle

This state kills existing processes and does nothing otherwise.

Maintain

This state starts missing processes and restarts processes that are not alive anymore.

Manager

PGSignals

An enumeration.

ProcessGroup

Robustly manage the lifecycle of a group of Dragon processes using Dragon Global Services.

Running

Stop

Stops all processes of the group and removes the group from the Manager.

Exceptions

DragonProcessGroupAbnormalExit

Exception raised by the Dragon Pool Workers implementation

DragonProcessGroupError

Exceptions raised by the Dragon Pool Workers implementation

Exception raised by the Dragon Pool Workers implementation

class PGSignalsÔÉÅ

An enumeration.

class BaseStateÔÉÅ

This class declares methods that all concrete State classes should implement and also provides a backreference to the Context object, associated with the State. This backreference can be used by States to transition the Context to another State. It also defines common methods and data structures to all states.

property contextÔÉÅ

Link back to it‚Äôs own context.

Returns

The group context holding this state

Return type

GroupContext

abstract run(prior_state, signal: PGSignals, sig_id: int) → NoneÔÉÅ

This method runs the state it is a part of on the context.

class ErrorÔÉÅ

This is the fallback state if an issue with the group occurs. The state of the processes is undefined here.

run(prior_state: BaseState, signal: PGSignals, sig_id: int) → NoneÔÉÅ

This method runs the state it is a part of on the context.

class IdleÔÉÅ

This state kills existing processes and does nothing otherwise.

run(prior_state: BaseState, signal: PGSignals, sig_id: int) → NoneÔÉÅ

The idle state just does nothing except making sure all processes are gone.

class MaintainÔÉÅ

This state starts missing processes and restarts processes that are not alive anymore.

Raises

DragonProcessGroupError ‚Äì If one of the processes could not be (re)started.

run(prior_state: BaseState, signal: PGSignals, sig_id: int) → NoneÔÉÅ

This method runs the state it is a part of on the context.

class RunningÔÉÅ
run(prior_state: BaseState, pgsignal: PGSignals, sig_id: int) → NoneÔÉÅ

This method runs the state it is a part of on the context.

class StopÔÉÅ

Stops all processes of the group and removes the group from the Manager. The group cannot be restarted anymore.

run(prior_state: BaseState, signal: PGSignals, sig_id: int) → NoneÔÉÅ

This method runs the state it is a part of on the context.

class GroupContextÔÉÅ

The Context defines the group interface for the manager and the client. In particular, it handles signals and state changes. It maintains a reference to an instance of a State subclass, which represents the current state of the group of processes.

__init__(templates: list[tuple], nproc: int, restart: bool, ignore_error_on_exit: bool, pmi_enabled: bool, walltime: float, policy: Policy) → NoneÔÉÅ

This class represents a group of processes and exposes an interface to the Manager to handle signals and state transitions.

Parameters

  • templates (list[tuple(int, dragon.native.process.TemplateProcess),]) ‚Äì a list of tuples where each tuple contains a replication factor n and a Dragon TemplateProcess object specifing the properties of the process to start. The processes can hold the same or different attributes in any way and will be numbered in order.

  • nproc (int) ‚Äì total number of processes that belong to the ProcessGroup

  • restart (bool) ‚Äì wether to restart processes that exited prematurely, defaults to True

  • ignore_error_on_exit (bool) ‚Äì whether to ignore errors when the group exists, defaults to False

  • pmi_enabled (bool) ‚Äì wether to instruct Dragon to enable MPI support, defaults to False

  • walltime (float) ‚Äì time in seconds to run processes before killing them.

  • policy (dragon.infrastructure.policy.Policy) ‚Äì determines the placement of the group resources

handle_signal(signal: PGSignals) → tupleÔÉÅ

This method takes a signal, checks if the signal is allowed, given the current state, and returns the new state. If the walltime is up, it overwrites the signal with kill.

Parameters

signal (Signal) ‚Äì The signal to consider

Returns

target state

Return type

BaseState

Raises

RuntimeError ‚Äì raised, if the transition is not allowed

Transition the context to a new state. This does NOT run the new state or updates the status.

Parameters

Returns

class ProcessGroupÔÉÅ

Robustly manage the lifecycle of a group of Dragon processes using Dragon Global Services.

This is really a state machine of the underlying processes. We should always be able to ‚Äúask‚Äù the manager process for the state of the group and send it a signal to make a state transition.

__init__(restart: bool = True, ignore_error_on_exit: bool = False, pmi_enabled: bool = False, walltime: Optional[float] = None, policy: Optional[Policy] = None)ÔÉÅ

Instantiate a number of Dragon processes.

Parameters

  • restart (bool) ‚Äì if True, restart worker processes that exit unexpectedly and suppress any errors from them, defaults to True.

  • ignore_error_on_exit (bool) ‚Äì If to ignore errors coming from processes when they exit from Join state.

  • flags (Worker.Flags) ‚Äì optional flags that affect the handling of a worker process.

  • pmi_enabled (Bool) ‚Äì Instruct the runtime to setup the environment so that the binary can use MPI for inter-process communication.

  • walltime (float) ‚Äì Time in seconds until the processes in the group get killed

  • policy (dragon.infrastructure.policy.Policy) ‚Äì determines the placement of the processes

add_process(nproc: int, template: TemplateProcess) → NoneÔÉÅ

Add processes to the ProcessGroup.

Parameters

  • template (dragon.native.process.TemplateProcess) ‚Äì single template processes, i.e. unstarted process objects

  • nproc (int) ‚Äì number of Dragon processes to start that follow the provided template

init() → NoneÔÉÅ

Initialize the GroupContext and Manager.

start() → NoneÔÉÅ

Starts up all processes according to the templates. If restart == False, transition to ‚ÄòRunning‚Äô, otherwise transition to ‚ÄòMaintain‚Äô.

join(timeout: Optional[float] = None) → NoneÔÉÅ

Wait for all processes to complete and the group to transition to Idle state. If the group status is ‚ÄòMaintain‚Äô, transition to ‚ÄòRunning‚Äô.

Raises TimeoutError, if the timeout occurred.

Parameters

timeout (float) ‚Äì Timeout in seconds, optional defaults to None

Returns

True if the timeout occured, False otherwise

Retype

bool

kill(signal: Signals = Signals.SIGKILL) → NoneÔÉÅ

Send a signal to each process of the process group.

The signals SIGKILL and SIGTERM have the following side effects:

  • If the signal is SIGKILL, the group will transition to ‚ÄòIdle‚Äô. It can then be reused.

  • If the group status is ‚ÄòMaintain‚Äô, SIGTERM will transition it to ‚ÄòRunning‚Äô.

  • If the group status is ‚ÄòError‚Äô, SIGTERM will raise a DragonProcessGroupError.

Parameters

signal (signal.Signals, optional) ‚Äì the signal to send, defaults to signal.SIGKILL

stop() → NoneÔÉÅ

Forcibly terminate all workers by sending SIGKILL from any state, transition to Stop. This also removes the group from the manager process and marks the end of the group life-cycle.

property puids: list[int]ÔÉÅ

Return the puids of the processes contained in this group.

Returns

a list of puids

Return type

list[int or None]

property status: strÔÉÅ

Get the current status of the process group handled by this instance.

Returns

current status of the group

Return type
